message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, which can present with abdominal pain, vomiting, and blurry vision. The serum digoxin level of 4 ng/mL indicates toxicity, and hyperkalemia is the most common electrolyte abnormality associated with digoxin toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause abnormal heart rhythms and hyperkalemia, which is an elevated potassium level. The serum digoxin level in this case is above the therapeutic range, indicating toxicity. Hypermagnesemia and hypercalcemia are not associated with digoxin toxicity, while hypokalemia can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity but is not the most likely electrolyte abnormality in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, which is consistent with the symptoms of the irregular pulse and abdominal pain. The other electrolyte abnormalities are not commonly associated with digoxin toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, which can lead to abdominal pain, vomiting, and blurry vision. The serum digoxin level being above the therapeutic range further supports the suspicion of digoxin toxicity. Hypermagnesemia can also occur with digoxin toxicity, but it is not the most likely electrolyte abnormality to be present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can lead to hyperkalemia, therefore option (B) is the correct answer. Digoxin inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an intracellular accumulation of potassium which can cause arrhythmia and other symptoms. Hypermagnesemia and hypercalcemia are not related to digoxin toxicity, and hypokalemia would usually exacerbate digoxin toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, which can lead to the symptoms and elevated serum digoxin levels seen in this patient. Hypermagnesemia and hypercalcemia are less likely to be associated with digoxin toxicity, and hypokalemia is actually a risk factor for digoxin toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, and the symptoms present in the boy are indicative of this. Hypermagnesemia and hypercalcemia are not commonly associated with digoxin toxicity, and hypokalemia is an unlikely cause of the symptoms given the boy’s serum digoxin level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an accumulation of intracellular potassium. Hypermagnesemia can also be present with digoxin toxicity, but hyperkalemia is more common. Hypokalemia is not expected with digoxin toxicity. Hypercalcemia is not related to digoxin toxicity.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Digoxin toxicity can cause hyperkalemia, especially in children. None of the other options are associated with digoxin toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. One of the toxic effects of digoxin is to block the Na+/K+ ATPase, leading to an increase in intracellular sodium and calcium, and a decrease in intracellular potassium. Thus, hyperkalemia is the most likely electrolyte abnormality in this patient.
